description.narrative: Given the climatic conditions and rich prevalence of water bodies, cultivation and catching of fish are an integral part of the Bangladeshi rural livelihood and its national cuisine. Fish is the most important source of protein to the population. The total fish production in Bangladesh is estimated to be 4.2 MN MT per annum, of which over 50% is farmed in closed water bodies. The aquaculture sector has been growing steadily over the last couple of decades due to rising demand and depleting fish stocks in rivers and marine areas. The sector is facing several challenges, including low productivity, lack of technology and know-how on sustainable farming practices, non-existent of cage culture, etc. However, with the shift of the industry from extensive to intensive production methods means that for example there will be an increasing need for quality professional feeds and veterinary inputs to contain diseases. This can offer business opportunities for the Dutch private sector, although reliable information with regard to the Bangladeshi market potential are now largely still unknown. Hence, this study aims to map the aquaculture sector in Bangladesh, its key actors and linkages, trends, issues, challenges and (business) opportunities. The outcome will:(i) provide to-the-point details for Dutch companies and institutes active in the aquaculture value chain to elevate the aquaculture sector of Bangladesh through investments and/or knowledge and technology, and(ii) provide further insight and pave ways for interventions to relevant supervisory, facilitating and regulatory bodies and key chain actors in Bangladesh.With the overall purpose to realise growth in the aquaculture sector of Bangladesh in a sustainable and responsible manner.
